segments.text: I'd like this interview to be sort of chronological in nature.
First, I'd like for you to tell me how you became interested in science.
In science?
Why, I became interested in science as a small boy through an interest in natural history.
And, well, first I collected the butterflies.
I was an eight-year-old or thereabouts.
And then I became interested in birds, and I got to be a pretty good ornithologist, I think.
I was an amateur and belonged to the professional bird club in Philadelphia, near which I grew up.
And by the time I went to college and realized that I had to make up my mind about something, I decided that the thing which I would do best in was something I was interested in.
And I was interested in natural history.
And the way you made your living in those days in natural history was to be a professor of biology, you see.
So that, I think, answers your question.
Where did you go to school?
Well, I went to the public schools in the town that I lived in until I was ready for high school.
Then I went to the Harvard School, which is a good private school near Philadelphia.
And then I went to Harvard College for one year, and then transferred to Harvard, where I took my bachelor's degree and my doctor's degree.
And you majored in biology at Harvard, right?
Yes.
What brought you to Woods Hole?
The Marine Biological Laboratory.
When did you come?
I think it was in 19...
which would have been the second year I graduated in 1913 as a member of the class of 1914 at Harvard.
I went through it three years, having been for one additional year at Harvard College, because I had four years of college, but only three years at Harvard.
And then the...

the first year of graduate study I I had a job which as sort of a tutor and then the second year I came to Woods Hole and I worked in the laboratory of the Bureau of Fisheries the reason I worked there was that for some reason which I am not clear about when the
Bureau Fisheries Laboratory was built in Woods Hole back in the 70s.

It was arranged, I suspect by Alexander Agassiz, that Harvard and Yale and Princeton and one or two other colleges, perhaps, were to have working tables for their people during the summer in that laboratory.
So I went there as a Harvard graduate student.
I didn't work on physics at all.
My doctor's thesis, which I was working on then, was on horned toads, which are lizards, which I used to import from Texas.
And then the following year, I took the physiology course in the MBL.
And then following that, I did research there for quite a number of years until the Oceanographic Institution was founded.
And you were at the Oceanographic Institution when it was founded?
Yes, at the very beginning.
Yes.
What was your role there?
I was known, I think, as the senior biologist.
You see, Dr. Bigelow, who became the director,
And at the forum, a staff had practically no oceanographers in this country to draw on.
There were one or two young men, such as and Dr. who had worked at sea a good bit.
But there were practically no oceanographers
people devoting themselves primarily to the ocean.
They were either biologists or something else, some other kind of scientist.
And Bigelow hunted around for people of that sort who he could persuade could find the ocean a profitable place to make their studies.
And I was one of the few physiologists who had paid any attention to marine animals.
I was then studying hemocyanin, which is the respiratory pigment of a number of groups of marine animals, analogous to hemoglobin, and was making naturally.
I think this is...
It's speculative, but I think this is the reason that I was selected.
I also knew Bigelow, but I don't think that was the particular reason.
But he did know who I was.
What sort of man was Bigelow like?
Well, I'd like to refer you to a memorial which I wrote for the National Academy of Science following his death.
Do you know that series?
Yes.
Yes.
But you'll find in a very recent volume of that a paper, a fairly long paper, about Bigelow, which I think will answer that question better than anything I can give off the cuff.
When you came to Woods Hole and began to do your science, did you immediately go to sea?
No.
I had this work to finish up.
And I worked on that for several summers until I exhausted the immediate obvious possibilities.
Bigelow, however, as I say in my article about him, insisted that the members of the staff all go to sea.
he arranged that each of us would have perhaps a week on the Atlantis to do whatever we wanted.
So that I went to sea in that capacity.
And during the first, one of the first winters, I undertook to make a survey of the Gulf of Maine, which he had studied.
very extensively, previously.
But he had worked with ships which he could borrow from time to time.
And his, although he covered all of the months in his surveys, except that during which there was part of shooting.
Yeah.
They were not synchronous, you see, or continuous.

They were scattered all over a period of perhaps 10 years, whereas I undertook to go out on the average of every five or six weeks and make a survey and go about the same ground, you see, so as to get a strictly comparable picture of the seasonal changes which occurred.
And this was really then your first work in oceanography, was this survey.
Yes.
And by that time, remember, I was at least 40 years old.
I forget exactly, 40 to 50 years old.
So I have never felt that I was acquainted with the background of oceanography as I am with the, or was with the background of physiology, which I taught for quite a number of years.
Yeah, except, you know, that most scientists who came into oceanography came in with no prior oceanographic training.
They just... Well, there was none.
There was none.
Just became oceanographers.
Yes.
And frequently were marine biologists.
Yes.
Or biologists who... Well, during that first year, there were a half a dozen people here at Woods Hole and a few similar people at Scripps.
We were the only really well-established oceanographic institutions
They had a department at the University of Washington, but that was fairly local, I think.
What was your first experience at sea like?
Did you like it immediately?
Well, I had grown up down here on the Cape as a boy in the summer, so I was used to boats and used to the water, and there was nothing surprising.
I liked it.
I discovered that it was very hard work.
Oh, yeah?
Yeah, because...
You had to be up and working whenever the ship got to the place that you wanted it to be.
And in a small area, such as the Gulf of Maine, that was only every few hours.
So it was very hard work.
And that was continuously being awake and sleeping only for a snatch here and there, as you could.
And I can remember
On one trip, which I went and had no one to help me, I didn't take my clothes off or my shoes off for two or three weeks.
Simply didn't have time.
I did the work on deck, and then I went and laid down on my bunk, and they woke me up when I got to the next place.
And I got up and did what I had to do and laid down on my bunk again.
So it was very hard work.
Of course, on a large ocean voyage, it takes longer.
The positions are spaced out at greater distances.
So it doesn't that work.
So I think the modern oceanography has a very easy time compared to what we have.
They have very much more luxurious ships and more comfortable.
Who were your colleagues here in the early years?
At the Oceanographic.
Oh, at the Oceanographic.
Yes.

My colleagues, that is, the heads of the different, I won't call them departments, because they were not departments, but of the different groups, were, first of all, Carl Rossby, who was a meteorologist at Tech, Selman Waxman, who was a bacteriologist from Rutgers, Norris Raichstraw, who was a chemist from Brown,
Those are the three that come to my mind.
There must have been more.
Did you guys collaborate a lot on your work?
Did you exchange ideas?
We knew each other pretty well.
I don't think we actually collaborated unless we worked together.
I think if you look over the papers, you will find very few joint-page papers.
But the institution was so, so small that we knew each other very well.
Now, you didn't just continue your work here on the bay, though.
What do you do next?
Well, as I say, this took about a year and a half to study the Gulf of Maine.
And I made one trip.
as far as to Bermuda and the Saw, which of course was very little.
And that's about the limit of my seagoing experience.
A few short trips locally, but really very small compared to what the boys do today.
They think nothing of going around the world.
Yeah, yeah.
In the development of the early institution, how did you try to encourage it to grow?
In the development of the early institution, how did you try to encourage it to grow?
What kind of people did you try to bring into the oceanographic institution?
Well, I don't think we thought too much about that.
In the first place, we were not particularly interested in growth.
It was never conceived that this would become the great institution that it has become today.
Dr. Bigelow was not that kind of a person.
He had no ambition, no grand ambitions.
He believed very much in doing good, honest work.
He believed very much in observation, much more than, I think, than thought.
That was perhaps his weakness.
And so what we were concerned with was doing what we were trying to do and to bring our students up to do likewise.
My students during that period, the only one that I think has become an oceanographer was Dr. Ketchum, who came down with me.
He was my graduate student at Harvard.
And he came down in the summers.
And I sent him off on the ship.
And we published a paper together, which I think was quite a good paper, quite an important paper at the time.
The other students that I brought down were students at the Harvard Medical School.
Well, let's see.
They, I guess, they were before the oceanographic and worked with me at the... At the lab?
At the MBL and at the Harvard Medical School.
They were medical students.
And so primarily then you just sort of brought students with you, I'm to take it, as they worked here in the early days of the oceanographic institution?
Yes, yes.
And, of course, after that first period of nine or ten years, the war broke out.
And that changed things entirely.
In what way?
Well, we weren't working on our own problems.
We were working on the problems which the government asked us to study, chiefly the Navy.
Right.
And the first project was the development of anti-fouling paints.
which was started under Dr. Waxman, because at that time there was the idea that bacterial slimes which formed on the bottom of the ship were important.
And I don't know just why he dropped out of it, but by the time it was pretty obvious that we were going to become engaged in the war, but before we were in the war, I was asked to come down and
take charge of that.
And I've been here ever since.
And your first work, then, was on these anti-fouling paints.
Yes.
Who worked on that with you?
Dr. Ketchum was the chief one.
Dr. Ferre, who is a physical chemist now at Wisconsin, and was then, I guess, at Harvard, a graduate student.
Dr. Wren, who was a bacteriologist.
one of Dr. Watson's students.
Then we recruited quite a number of additional students.
There were three or four men from Yale who were students chiefly of Evelyn Hutchinson, Dr. Edmondson, and Dr. Hutchins.
And I don't think Dr. Riley actually worked with me or with the troupe.
There was one other, Dr. Deeby.
And from any fouling paints, then what did you do?
Well, then I became also...
I became interested in the problem of submarine diving.
And they had developed here the bathythermograph, which you've heard about.
And they were developing one to use on a submarine.
And I had ideas about that.
They were not successful ideas.
And so I was asked to sort of look over
Mr. Vine's shoulder, who was working on the one which was ultimately adapted.
And so I spent a good part of the war years also working on that problem, and particularly in instructing the crews of submarines how to use this instrument.
And I made a good many cruises out of New London and Portsmouth
with new submarines and new cruisers and new, new, new crews instructing them in this matter of underwater sound.
At the end of the war, I wrote a book on the underwater operation of submarines.
That's right.
I have never, the war ended about the time that book was published.
I have only seen one copy, which Vine swiped off somebody's desk.
That's right.
The only copy I've ever seen Vine has.
Yes.
I've never seen any except that.
I have no copy of it, but I wrote the only word of it.
Did you work with Vine in this?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, he was working on this instrument, you see.
Yeah.
And I was seeing that he got something done, essentially what I was doing.
Yeah.
And we worked together on an instrument called the STD.
S-T-D. Salinity Temperature Depth, which was a device which you could lower and it sort of measured the salinity temperature and depth of the water that went through.
And that has gone through some evolution and is still used.
Yes.
When did you first meet Roger Revell?
I think it must have been in Washington.
I can't remember the place.
I can remember the time very well.
I went into this office, and here was my idea of a beautiful young naval officer.
I don't know whether you are old enough to remember, but at that time in these subway cars,
There were advertisements, you know.
And there were naval recruiting advertisements to join the Navy and see the world, that sort of thing.
And there was always a beautiful, very handsome young officer with a high, stiff collar, usually, and a beautiful cap, you see.
And here was the living image of this fellow.
And he was Mr. Reveille, Lieutenant Commandant, Lieutenant
I guess, at that time.
And then I worked for him when he became more authoritative in Washington.
I worked for him.
When did you go to work for him?
Huh?
When did you go to work for him?
Oh, I don't remember.
About 1946, wasn't it?
Well, 45 or 46.
In the organization of the early organization of ONR.
Yes.
What were you doing there?
What were you doing there?
Well, I wasn't there.
I was here in Woods Hole.
But I was studying things that they wanted to know, you see.
And I would make these studies and write reports on them and turn them into Roger.
And Roger would insist on rewriting them.
He would.
It made me so goddamn mad.
I am an amateur watercolor painter.
And I can remember at that time
I used to get so mad at Roger that I couldn't sleep.
And I would get up and I would turn on the electric light and I would get out my paints and I would paint pictures out of my head.
Pictures of boats, which I happen to know pretty well.
And they were the best pictures I've ever painted.
But they were all stimulated by the fact that Roger annoyed me so much.
What were you working on in 1946 and 1947 for ONR?
What was the next project?
Were you staying with submarines?
Yes, yes.
I worked for ONR on this submarine problem.
And, well, what I can remember was I got the idea.
I was familiar with the sailing directions, you see, which the government publishes, which tells you if you're operating a ship,
what you will encounter in various places, do you see?
The winds, the tides, the currents, the supplies, and so on.
An invaluable source of information for the man who was operating a ship and going anywhere.
And I thought that it would be useful to get a submarine supplement to sailing directions, which would tell the submarine skipper
what he might expect if he operated his ship in certain waters, in terms of the hydrography of that area.
And so I wrote.
It was at the time they were planning the invasion of North Africa.
And I wrote a submarine supplement covering the Bay of Biscay from which they would naturally land.
It was the first submarine subloan.
I guess I'm old fashioned.
I like to see things in black and white written in sentences as short and explicit as possible.
That doesn't go, apparently.
You have to be funny.
So they took the job of writing in some future summary supplements away from me and gave it to a man, I think his name was George Stewart, who was quite a good novelist.
on the West Coast.
And they were sort of Hollywood productions, and I felt, well, nothing of them.
I don't know whether anybody ever read any of them.
When the war is over, you stay here at Woods Hole.
What's your first job at Woods Hole, then?
What?
When the war is over, you remain at Woods Hole.
What do you do with the osteographing institution then?
Well, my job was to, of course...
I was the senior biologist.
I was responsible for the biological development here.
And my chief problem was to get money for biology.
The work on underwater sound, which the Oceanographic did through Iswin and Ewing, was so successful, you see, that it sold oceanography.
to the Navy and through them to the world.
But the Navy was not yet aware that there was any importance in biology.
So they were supporting physical oceanography, but there was no support for biological oceanography.
And the place that I found that I could develop support
with people who were private individuals or communities which were interested in pollution.
And that we knew something about estuaries and how to study the chemistry of coastal waters.
And it was on the basis of that that we got contracts with private individuals or private organizations.
The first one was with the National Lead Company.
Mm-hm.
They mine for titanium up in the Adirondacks.
And there's an interesting story to that, but it's nothing to do with this.
They carry it down to

near the mouth of the Rurican River, where they have a big chemical plant, and they refine it to get out titanium oxide, which is a white material, which is used for making porcelain, white, in bathtubs and all that sort of use.
And it's used in white paints as a substitute for...
lead oxide.
And so that was why the National Lead Company was interested in titanium, you see.
Titanium was replacing lead as a constituent in ordinary paints.
And they were sitting on as much titanium as they could sit on.
In the course of their chemical refinement of this ore, they had to treat it with sulfuric acid.
And they had a large amount of sulfuric acid and iron, which is also present in the ore, as a waste product.
And they started dumping that into the Raritan River.
And they made such a mess that the state very quickly said, you have got to stop dumping this stuff into the Raritan River.
You must dispose of it elsewhere.

And they found that they spent about, I think they told me, five or six million dollars trying to find some method of recovering material from this waste, which would pay for itself, and they couldn't find it.
And so they decided to barge it out to sea and dump it into the ocean.
And they had no sooner decided to do that, and it became known that they were going to do it,

then that there was a very smart sports writer in New York who wrote for, I think it was the American, who ran a column in the New York paper, American, for the benefit of the sport fishermen, you see.
And in this column, he began telling how this waste
was, not will, but was, running nets and so on and so on.
Before a drop of it had ever been put in the ocean.
These stories began circulating, you see, of very harmful effects.
Well, the National Lead Company had not a chemical problem, but a public relations problem.
Right.
And they engaged us to study their operations.
And I can remember they sent me an account of this barge, how big it was, how fast it was to be towed, how fast they were to pump out this material, what the chemical composition was.
And I studied it, and I made a very good, what turned out to be a very good prognostication of what was going to happen to the chemistry of the water.
And then when they finally got the barge built,
And they took it out with the first load of material.
We took a small ship from which hole and went down and we followed it.
And we zigzagged back and forth in its wake, measuring the seawater at different distances from the outpost.
